user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of is_slot_available:
```c
static bool
is_slot_available (const struct MHD_NonceNc *const nn,
                   const uint64_t now,
                   const char *const new_nonce,
                   size_t new_nonce_len)
{
  uint64_t timestamp;
  bool timestamp_valid;
  mhd_assert (new_nonce_len <= NONCE_STD_LEN (MAX_DIGEST));
  mhd_assert (NONCE_STD_LEN (MAX_DIGEST) <= MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH);
  if (0 == nn->nonce[0])
    return true; /* The slot is empty */

  if (0 == memcmp (nn->nonce, new_nonce, new_nonce_len))
  {
    /* The slot has the same nonce already. This nonce cannot be registered
     * again as it would just clear 'nc' usage history. */
    return false;
  }

  if (0 != nn->nc)
    return true; /* Client already used the nonce in this slot at least
                    one time, re-use the slot */

  /* The nonce must be zero-terminated */
  mhd_assert (0 == nn->nonce[sizeof(nn->nonce) - 1]);
  if (0 != nn->nonce[sizeof(nn->nonce) - 1])
    return true; /* Wrong nonce format in the slot */

  timestamp_valid = get_nonce_timestamp (nn->nonce, 0, &timestamp);
  mhd_assert (timestamp_valid);
  if (! timestamp_valid)
    return true; /* Invalid timestamp in nonce-nc, should not be possible */

  if ((REUSE_TIMEOUT * 1000) < TRIM_TO_TIMESTAMP (now - timestamp))
    return true;

  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 21.14 concerns using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. The only use of memcmp in this function is the shown fragment, so it must be investigated to determine whether the operands are null-terminated strings and whether the length passed is appropriate. Other parts of the function do not use memcmp or perform string comparisons: checks like '0 == nn->nonce[0]', '0 != nn->nc', '0 == nn->nonce[sizeof(nn->nonce) - 1]' and the timestamp handling (get_nonce_timestamp, TRIM_TO_TIMESTAMP) operate on bytes/integers or call other functions and therefore are not relevant to Rule 21.14. The mhd_assert calls are diagnostics and not uses of memcmp or string comparison either. No other memcmp/string-compare occurrences exist in the provided code fragment.
